summary_points: 1.  Procter & Gamble's Q3 FY25 organic sales growth of 1% was solely due to price increases, with no volume growth.
2.  Despite projected 2% organic sales growth for FY25, net sales are predicted to be flat due to a 1-point foreign exchange headwind.
3.  Procter & Gamble forecasts FY25 core EPS growth of +2% to +4%, reduced by 1 percentage point to +3% to +5% on a currency-neutral basis.
1. Willis Towers Watson (WTW) reported a 5% decrease in Q1 2025 revenue to $2.2 billion, though organic revenue grew by 5%, primarily due to the sale of TRANZACT in December 2024.
2. WTW's long-term debt decreased significantly by $549 million year-over-year to $4,761 million as of March 31, 2025.
3. WTW anticipates additional cash outflows in 2025 to settle accrued costs from its completed Transformation program, impacting earnings until profitability from a new reinsurance joint venture.
1. Molina Healthcare acquired ConnectiCare for $350 million on February 1, 2025.
2.  First-quarter 2025 premium revenue increased 12% year-over-year to $10.6 billion, despite being partially offset by Medicaid redeterminations.
3. Molina Healthcare projects a 10 percentage point increase in its medical care ratio to 75% in 2026, resulting in a 7% increase in medical costs.
1. Pool Corporation's Q1 2025 net sales decreased 4% year-over-year, but same-selling day sales declined only 2%, consistent with Q4 2024 and an improvement from earlier in 2024.
2.  Q1 2025 earnings per diluted share decreased 30% year-over-year to $1.42,  but this included a $0.24 negative impact from the reversal of import taxes in 2024; without this, the decrease was 18%.
3. Pool Corporation confirms its full-year 2025 earnings guidance range of $11.10 to $11.60 per diluted share, which includes a $0.10 per share tax benefit.
1. Texas Instruments' Q1 2025 revenue increased 11% year-over-year to $4.07 billion.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Texas Instruments held $5.01 billion in total cash, a $2.58 billion decrease from the end of 2024.
3. Texas Instruments expects to receive up to $1.6 billion in funding from the U.S. CHIPS and Science Act for three 300mm wafer fabs, along with a 25% investment tax credit.
1. L3Harris Technologies' Q1 2025 net income increased by 38% year-over-year to $386 million.
2. The company divested its Commercial Aviation Solutions group for $831 million in net cash proceeds on March 28, 2025.
3. L3Harris anticipates incurring further non-recurring costs associated with the LHX NeXt initiative through 2026.
1. IPG reported a net loss of $85.3 million in Q1 2025, compared to a net income of $110.4 million in Q1 2024, primarily due to $203.3 million in restructuring charges.
2.  IPG's merger with Omnicom, expected to close in the second half of 2025, is subject to regulatory review, with the FTC issuing a Second Request for information on March 12, 2025.
3. IPG anticipates a $90.0 to $100.0 million decrease in unrecognized tax benefits over the next twelve months (as of April 24, 2025), impacting its effective income tax rate.
1. Interpublic Group reported a net loss of $85.4 million in Q1 2025, compared to a profit of $110.4 million in Q1 2024, primarily due to a $203.3 million restructuring charge.
2.  Interpublic Group's Q1 2025 organic net revenue decreased by 3.6% year-over-year, a smaller decline than predicted.
3.  Interpublic Group projects a 1% to 2% decrease in full-year 2025 organic revenue and expects its acquisition by Omnicom to close in the second half of 2025.
1. Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP) acquired a 60% stake in GHOST Lifestyle for $999 million in December 2024.
2. KDP's net income increased 13.9% year-over-year to $517 million in Q1 2025, while net sales increased 5.1% to $3.635 billion.
3. KDP anticipates $125 million to $145 million in pre-tax restructuring charges through the second half of 2025.
1. PMI's Q1 2025 net earnings increased 25% year-over-year to $2.69 billion, while net revenues increased 5.8% to $9.3 billion.
2.  PMI anticipates at least $230 million in pre-tax charges in Q2 2025 due to German factory closures, along with an additional $1 million in future cash exit costs.
3.  PMI's short-term debt significantly increased by $4.3 billion year-over-year as of March 31, 2025, contrasting with a decrease in long-term debt.
1. MSCI Inc.'s annual meeting on April 22, 2025, saw all board members elected, and proposals concerning executive compensation and the 2025 Omnibus Incentive Plan were approved.
2.  A majority of votes cast (for or against) were affirmative for each director elected to the Board.
3. PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was ratified as MSCI Inc.'s independent auditor for fiscal year 2025.
1. Valero Energy Corporation reported a net loss of $595 million ($1.90 per share) for the first quarter of 2025, compared to a net income of $1.2 billion ($3.75 per share) in Q1 2024.
2.  The Refining segment reported an operating loss of $530 million in Q1 2025, a significant decrease from the $1.7 billion operating income in Q1 2024.
3. Valero plans to complete a $230 million FCC Unit optimization project at its St. Charles Refinery in 2026, which is expected to increase high-value product yields.
1. FCX's Q1 2025 copper sales (872 million pounds) exceeded guidance, while gold sales fell significantly short (128,000 ounces vs. 225,000 ounces guidance).
2. Proposed U.S. tariffs are projected to reduce FCX's annual revenue by $300 million starting November 2025, impacting U.S. copper production by potentially 300 million pounds.
3.  FCX's Q1 2025 net income was reported variously as $352 million and $600 million, exceeding expectations, though the discrepancy requires clarification.

1. On April 23, 2025, Autodesk, Inc. entered into a cooperation agreement with Starboard Value, resulting in the appointment of two new directors, Jeff Epstein and Anna Christine Simons, to the board, effective after the 2025 Annual Meeting on June 18, 2025.
2. Starboard Value, holding approximately 0.9% of Autodesk's outstanding common stock, agreed to a standstill period until at least 100 days before the first anniversary of the 2025 Annual Meeting.
3. Autodesk will reimburse Starboard up to $500,000 for reasonable expenses incurred from August 1, 2024, through April 23, 2025.
1. Bernard Birkett, West Pharmaceutical Services, Inc.'s CFO, will retire later this year.
2. Shane Campbell, newly appointed SVP, received a $1,000,000 LTI award with a ten-year clawback provision, currently inactive as his employment starts May 5, 2025.
3. Shane Campbell's offer letter materials, included in the SEC filing, contain at least ten photographs.

1. Union Pacific Corporation's first-quarter 2025 earnings per diluted share remained flat at $2.70 compared to $2.69 in the first quarter of 2024, despite a 7% headwind from fuel costs and the leap year.
2.  First-quarter 2025 revenue carloads increased by 7% year-over-year, while freight revenue excluding fuel surcharges grew by 4%.

3.  Union Pacific affirms its 2025 outlook, projecting earnings per share growth consistent with a 3-year compound annual growth rate target of high-single to low-double digits,  despite volume being impacted by mixed economic conditions and challenging year-over-year international intermodal comparisons.
1. West Pharmaceutical Services increased its full-year 2025 adjusted diluted EPS guidance to $6.15-$6.35,  as of April 24, 2025.
2.  First-quarter 2025 diluted EPS decreased by 21% year-over-year, while adjusted diluted EPS decreased by 7%.
3. The company expects $20-$25 million in tariff costs to negatively impact full-year 2025 earnings.
1. Nasdaq, Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 net revenue of $1.2 billion, an 11% increase year-over-year (YoY), and adjusted net revenue growth of 12.5%.
2.  Financial Technology revenue increased by 10% YoY to $432 million in Q1 2025, with Financial Crime Management Technology revenue up 21% YoY.
3. Nasdaq is updating its 2025 non-GAAP operating expense guidance to a range of $2,265 million to $2,325 million, while maintaining its non-GAAP tax rate guidance.
1. Fiserv Inc. reported GAAP revenue growth of 5% and organic revenue growth of 7% for the first quarter of 2025, exceeding expectations with a 14% increase in adjusted EPS.
2.  For the first quarter of 2025, GAAP earnings per share increased by 22% to $1.51, compared to $1.24 in the first quarter of 2024.

3. Fiserv affirms its 2025 outlook of 10% to 12% organic revenue growth and adjusted EPS of $10.10 to $10.30 (representing growth of 15% to 17%), anticipating acceleration in the second half of the year.
1. Dow Inc. reported a GAAP net loss of $290 million for the first quarter of 2025, compared to a GAAP net income of $538 million in the first quarter of 2024.
2.  Year-over-year net sales were down 3%, primarily due to lower local prices across all operating segments, while volume increased by 2%.
3. Dow Inc. plans to implement cost-cutting measures and asset sales totaling approximately $6 billion by 2026 to offset the impact of an extended industry downcycle.
1. Procter & Gamble's fiscal year 2025 third-quarter net sales decreased by 2%, while organic sales (excluding foreign exchange and acquisitions/divestitures) increased by 1%.
2.  For fiscal year 2025, P&G updated its diluted net earnings per share growth guidance to a range of 6% to 8%, compared to fiscal year 2024's diluted net EPS of $6.02.

3.  P&G anticipates approximately $200 million after-tax headwinds from commodity costs and unfavorable foreign exchange rates in fiscal year 2025, along with a roughly $0.04 headwind to core EPS from net interest expense and the absence of prior year divestiture benefits.
1. Ameriprise Financial Inc. reported adjusted operating earnings per diluted share of $9.50 for the first quarter of 2025, a 13% increase year-over-year.
2.  GAAP net income per diluted share was $5.83 for Q1 2025, significantly lower than the $9.46 reported in Q1 2024, primarily due to unfavorable market impacts on derivative valuations.

3. Ameriprise announced a new $4.5 billion share repurchase program, extending to June 30, 2027, and an 8% increase in its quarterly dividend, reflecting strong free cash flow generation and excess capital.

1. Tractor Supply Company's first-quarter 2025 net sales increased by 2.1% to $3.47 billion, driven by new store openings and Allivet's contribution, but offset by a 0.9% decrease in comparable store sales.

2.  Full-year 2025 net sales guidance was widened to a 4% to 8% increase from the previous 5% to 7% prediction, due to increased market uncertainty, particularly new tariffs introduced since January 30, 2025.

3. The company provided second-quarter 2025 guidance predicting net sales growth of approximately 3% to 4%, with comparable store sales growth projected to be flat to up 1%, and diluted earnings per share between $0.79 and $0.81.
1. CBRE Group, Inc. reported GAAP EPS up 32% to $0.54 and Core EPS up 10% to $0.86 for the first quarter of 2025, as of April 24, 2025.
2.  Revenue increased by 12% to $8.9 billion, and net revenue rose 15% to $5.1 billion in Q1 2025 compared to Q1 2024.
3.  Current market uncertainty, driven by tariff issues, has reduced the clarity of CBRE's future outlook, although current activity levels and new business pipelines remain strong.
1. L3Harris Technologies, Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 diluted EPS of $2.04 on revenue of $5.1 billion, compared to $1.48 diluted EPS and $5.211 billion in revenue during the same period in 2024.

2.  As of April 24, 2025, L3Harris updated its 2025 guidance, projecting non-GAAP diluted EPS of $10.30-$10.50, down from a prior projection of $10.55-$10.85, primarily due to the divestiture of its Commercial Aviation Solutions business.

3.  The company anticipates approximately $525 million in reduced IMS revenue and a margin reduction for the remainder of 2025, following the divestiture of its Commercial Aviation Solutions business.
1. Hasbro's Q1 2025 revenue increased 17%, driven by a 46% surge in the Wizards and Digital Gaming segment, while Consumer Products slightly underperformed, declining 4%.
2.  Adjusted operating profit for Q1 2025 was $222 million, a $74 million increase year-over-year, resulting in a 25.1% margin (a 5.5-point improvement).
3. Hasbro maintained its full-year guidance issued on February 20, 2025, despite uncertainty surrounding the current tariff environment.
1. Merck's total worldwide sales for the first quarter of 2025 were $15.5 billion, a 2% decrease year-over-year; however, excluding foreign exchange impacts, sales grew by 1%.
2.  KEYTRUDA sales grew by 4% year-over-year to $7.2 billion in Q1 2025, while GARDASIL/GARDASIL 9 sales declined by 41% to $1.3 billion.

3. Merck revised its full-year 2025 non-GAAP EPS outlook downward to $8.82 to $8.97, primarily due to a newly anticipated one-time charge of approximately $0.06 per share related to a license agreement with Hengrui Pharma.
1. Dover Corp's Q1 2025 revenue decreased 0.9% year-over-year to $1.9 billion despite acquisition-related growth, primarily driven by a 2.7% decline from dispositions.
2.  As of April 24, 2025, Dover Corp. expects to recognize 73.1% of its unsatisfied performance obligations as revenue through 2026.
3. Dover Corp. completed the acquisition of Cryogenic Machinery Corp. in Q1 2025 for $29,287,000 (net of cash acquired), resulting in preliminary goodwill and intangible assets.
1. Dover Corp's Q1 2025 GAAP earnings from continuing operations decreased by 60% year-over-year to $239 million, primarily due to a gain on the disposition of De-Sta-Co in Q1 2024.
2.  Adjusted Q1 2025 diluted EPS increased by 19% year-over-year to $2.05.
3. Dover anticipates full-year 2025 GAAP EPS from continuing operations between $8.04 and $8.24 (adjusted EPS between $9.20 and $9.40), based on 2% to 4% revenue growth.
1. Textron Inc. sold its Powersports business, including the Arctic Cat brand, on April 23, 2025.
2. First-quarter 2025 revenues increased by $171 million year-over-year to $3.3 billion, while GAAP EPS was $1.13 compared to $1.03 in Q1 2024 and adjusted EPS was $1.28 compared to $1.20 in Q1 2024.

3. Textron reaffirmed its 2025 financial outlook, predicting GAAP EPS from continuing operations of $5.19 to $5.39, or $6.00 to $6.20 on an adjusted basis, and net cash provided by operating activities for the manufacturing group to be between $1.2 billion and $1.3 billion.

1. LKQ Corp's Q1 2025 revenue was $3.5 billion, a 6.5% decrease year-over-year, primarily due to a 4.3% decrease in organic parts and services revenue and negative impacts from acquisitions/divestitures and foreign exchange rates.
2. While diluted EPS increased by 10.2% year-over-year to $0.65, adjusted diluted EPS decreased by 3.7% to $0.79.

3.  LKQ Corp's 2025 full-year outlook remains unchanged from February 20, 2025, projecting 0% to 2% organic revenue growth and $2.91 to $3.21 diluted EPS, but this excludes any potential impact from tariffs, which remains uncertain.
1. Keurig Dr Pepper's Q1 2025 net sales grew 4.8% (6.4% constant currency), exceeding expectations with strong growth in the U.S. Refreshment Beverages segment.

2.  Full-year 2025 guidance, reaffirmed on April 24, 2025, predicts mid-single-digit constant currency net sales growth and high-single-digit adjusted diluted EPS growth, reduced by approximately one percentage point due to foreign currency translation.
3. The U.S. Refreshment Beverages segment demonstrated strong volume/mix growth in Q1 2025, contributing significantly to the overall positive results.
1. CenterPoint Energy's Q1 2025 earnings decreased year-over-year to $0.45 per diluted share (GAAP) and $0.53 (non-GAAP), compared to $0.55 in both measures during Q1 2024.
2.  CenterPoint Energy's interconnection queue grew by approximately 7 GW between the end of 2024 and April 24, 2025.
3. The company increased its 10-year capital investment plan by $1 billion to a total of $48.5 billion as of April 24, 2025.

1. Allegion plc's Q1 2025 net revenues increased by 5.4% year-over-year to $941.9 million, driven by higher volumes and acquisitions, despite currency headwinds and softness in the residential business.
2.  The impact of newly announced US government tariffs on Allegion's imports in 2025 remains uncertain.
3. Allegion completed three acquisitions in 2025 (Next Door Company, Lemaar Pty Ltd, and Trimco Hardware), with a disclosed acquisition cost of approximately $11.1 million for two of them.
1. CenterPoint Energy sold its Louisiana and Mississippi natural gas LDC businesses for $1.2 billion on March 31, 2025.
2.  CenterPoint Energy's Q1 2025 net income decreased by $53 million year-over-year, despite a $20 million increase in operating income.
3.  The company faces potential litigation costs from Hurricane Beryl ranging from $50 million to $150 million, as of April 24, 2025.
1. Allegion plc reported first-quarter 2025 net revenues of $941.9 million and net earnings of $148.2 million ($1.71 per share), representing a 5.4% and 21.3% increase year-over-year, respectively.
2.  Adjusted operating margin increased by 150 basis points year-over-year to 22.7% in Q1 2025, driven by favorable volume leverage, mix, and acquisitions.

3. Allegion affirmed its full-year 2025 outlook of a 1% to 3% reported revenue increase and a 1.5% to 3.5% organic revenue increase, with full-year EPS expected to be in the range of $7.05 to $7.25 (reported) or $7.65 to $7.85 (adjusted), as of April 24, 2025.
1. WTW's Q1 2025 revenue decreased 5% year-over-year to $2.2 billion, despite 5% organic revenue growth, primarily due to the sale of TRANZACT.
2.  Diluted EPS increased 27% year-over-year to $2.33 in Q1 2025, but a reinsurance joint venture with Bain Capital is projected to reduce adjusted diluted EPS by $0.25 to $0.35 in 2025.
3. WTW plans to repurchase approximately $1.5 billion of its shares in 2025.
1. News Corp's stock repurchase program, authorized for up to $1 billion, had repurchased approximately $664,424,831.42 worth of Class A and Class B shares by April 23, 2025.
2. On April 23, 2025,  21,621,281 Class A shares and 10,671,365 Class B shares were repurchased as part of the program.
3.  Future repurchases under the program are subject to market conditions, the market price of News Corp's stock, and other factors.
1. Chipotle's Q1 2025 revenue increased by 6.4% year-over-year to $2.9 billion, while diluted earnings per share rose by 7.7% to $0.28.
2. Newly enacted tariffs in April 2025 are projected to increase Chipotle's costs by 50 basis points permanently, with a 20 basis point increase expected in Q2 2025.
3. As of March 31, 2025, Chipotle held an accrued legal liability of $21,231,000.
1. PepsiCo's Q1 2025 GAAP net revenue decreased by 1.8%, and GAAP EPS decreased by 10%, as of March 22, 2025, while organic revenue increased by 1.2% and core EPS was $1.48.

2.  PepsiCo revised its 2025 financial guidance, now expecting core constant currency EPS to be approximately even with the prior year (previously expected mid-single-digit growth), resulting in a projected 3% decline in core EPS compared to 2024.

3.  PepsiCo anticipates increased supply chain costs due to global trade developments and subdued consumer conditions, impacting profitability and leading to a downward revision of its EPS growth prediction.
1. PepsiCo's diluted net income decreased by 10% year-over-year to $1,834 million in the twelve weeks ended March 22, 2025.
2.  PepsiCo expects $6.15 billion in pre-tax charges through 2030, with $5.1 billion in cash expenditures, related to its 2019 Productivity Plan.
3. PepsiCo completed two significant acquisitions in 2025: Siete for $1.2 billion and poppi for $1.95 billion (plus contingent consideration).

1. Xcel Energy's first-quarter 2025 GAAP and ongoing earnings per share were $0.84, down from $0.88 in the same period of 2024, primarily due to higher operating and maintenance expenses, depreciation, and interest charges, partially offset by increased infrastructure investment recovery.
2.  As of April 21, 2025, Xcel Energy Inc. and its subsidiaries had $2,993 million in available credit facilities, compared to $29,114 million in long-term debt.

3.  Xcel Energy estimates probable losses of $290 million (before insurance) related to the Smokehouse Creek Fire Complex (as of April 24, 2025),  potentially exceeding insurance coverage and materially impacting financials.
1. Starbucks advised shareholders to reject a mini-tender offer from Tutanota LLC for 500,000 shares at $88.00 per share on April 23, 2025.
2. This offer, expiring May 12, 2025, represents only 0.04% of Starbucks' outstanding stock.
3.  The unsolicited offer from Tutanota is considered by Starbucks to be unwelcome.
1. Intuitive Surgical's total revenue increased 19% year-over-year to $2.25 billion in Q1 2025.
2.  The company anticipates a significant adverse impact on future cost of revenue due to potential global tariffs.

3. Intuitive Surgical acquired European da Vinci and Ion distribution businesses for approximately €290 million, with potential additional payments of €31 million, with expected closure in the first half of 2026.
1. On April 23, 2025, Fastenal Company announced a two-for-one stock split, effective May 21, 2025, with trading expected to begin on a split-adjusted basis around May 22, 2025.
2.  The filing does not contain any year-over-year numerical comparisons of financial performance.
3. The filing mentions no specific future impacts or risks associated with the stock split.

1. On April 21, 2025, AutoZone, Inc. appointed Claire Rauh McDonough to its Board of Directors; she is the CFO of Rivian Automotive, Inc. and will serve on AutoZone's Audit and Compensation Committees.
2. As of February 15, 2025, AutoZone operated a total of 7,432 stores across the U.S., Mexico, and Brazil.
3.  No specific future impacts or risks are detailed in this filing.
1. Tyler Technologies Inc. reported total revenues of $565.2 million for the first quarter of 2025, a 10.3% increase year-over-year.
2.  GAAP net income for Q1 2025 was $81.1 million ($1.84 per diluted share), while Non-GAAP net income was $122.1 million ($2.78 per diluted share).
3. For the full year 2025, Tyler Technologies projects total revenues in the range of $2.31 billion to $2.35 billion, with a free cash flow margin expected between 24% and 26%.

1. United Rentals, Inc. announced a new $1.5 billion share repurchase program on April 23, 2025, planning to repurchase $1.25 billion in 2025 and complete the program by the end of the first quarter of 2026.
2.  First-quarter 2025 total revenue reached a record $3.719 billion, while net income decreased 4.4% year-over-year to $518 million.
3.  The company reaffirmed its 2025 full-year guidance, projecting total revenue between $15.6 billion and $16.1 billion and adjusted EBITDA between $7.2 billion and $7.45 billion.
1. O'Reilly Automotive reported a 3.6% increase in comparable store sales for the first quarter of 2025, exceeding their expectations.
2.  Net income for the first quarter of 2025 decreased by 2% to $538 million compared to $547 million in the same period of 2024, while diluted earnings per common share increased by 2% to $9.35.
3. The company maintains its full-year 2025 comparable store sales guidance range of 2.0% to 4.0%, but acknowledges significant uncertainty due to the changing tariff landscape.

1. At the 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders on April 17, 2025, a shareholder proposal requesting approval of certain executive officer severance arrangements was not approved, with 171,592,610 votes against, 10,375,593 votes for, and 699,297 abstentions.
2.  All ten nominees for director were elected at the April 17, 2025 shareholder meeting.

3. The proposal to ratify the appointment of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the Company’s independent registered public accounting firm for 2025 was approved by a significant margin (193,007,652 votes for versus 2,892,958 votes against).
1. Edwards Lifesciences Corp. reported Q1 2025 sales growth of 6.2% to $1.41 billion, exceeding expectations with 5.4% constant currency growth in TAVR sales.
2.  Year-over-year growth in Transcatheter Mitral and Tricuspid Therapies (TMTT) sales was 58%, reaching $115 million in Q1 2025.

3. Edwards Lifesciences Corp. is raising its 2025 TMTT sales guidance to $530–$550 million and increasing its total company sales guidance to $5.7–$6.1 billion (as of April 24, 2025), but anticipates pressure on operating margins due to currency fluctuations and tariffs.
1. Baker Hughes' Q1 2025 net income decreased by 10-12% year-over-year to $402 million, primarily due to losses in the fair value of equity securities.
2.  The company plans to reduce capital expenditures by 15% year-over-year in 2025, totaling $2.2 billion, reflecting lower expected E&P spending.
3.  Baker Hughes anticipates 89% of its $33.2 billion in remaining performance obligations to be recognized as revenue within 15 years of March 31, 2025.
1.  United Rentals' Q1 2025 net income decreased 4.4% year-over-year to $518 million, while adjusted EBITDA increased 5.3% to $1.671 billion.
2.  The company received a $64 million break-up fee in Q1 2025 following a terminated merger agreement.
3.  United Rentals plans to repurchase $1.5 billion of its shares in 2025, subject to a 1% excise tax.
1. Moody's Q1 2025 revenue increased 8% year-over-year to $1.924 billion.
2.  Moody's anticipates $145-$175 million in restructuring program cash outlays through 2027, with the majority of the remaining $47 million liability expected to be paid within the next year.
3.  Moody's expects 7-9% external revenue growth for the full year 2025 (as of April 24, 2025).
